data: Development and verification of an innovative full life sustainable approach to the valorisation of municipal solid waste into industrial feedstocks
Researchers are transforming municipal waste into renewable chemicals to unlock economic value and reduce environmental impact.

More than 180 million tonnes of municipal solid waste (MSW) are discarded in Europe every year. One way to reduce environmental impact and add economic value is to develop innovative ways to convert this waste stream into useful, renewable products.

The EU-funded http://www.waste2go.eu/ (WASTE2GO) project aims to develop and verify technologies that can transform more than 55 % of MSW into a source of sustainable, high-value chemicals.

As such, researchers have developed novel enzyme-based systems to digest, or breakdown, MSW. These enzymes are now produced in large volumes to facilitate small-scale digestion trials.

The project also introduced two novel engineering systems that are designed to effectively handle solid waste products. The aim is to successfully extract valuable chemicals at every stage of the digestion process.

This technology has already exceeded current approaches to biorefining, which use crop-derived feedstocks. Once complete, WASTE2GO will help strengthen Europe's leading position in innovative enzyme technology, while easing the environmental burden of MSW.
